description: Characterized by deficits in general mental abilities.
Results in impairments of adaptive functioning.
Disorder with onset during the developmental period that includes both intellectual and adaptive functioning deficits in conceptual, social, and practical domains.
Deficits in intellectual functions such as reasoning, problem solving, planning, abstract thinking, judgment, academic learning, and learning from experience.
Deficit in intellectual and adaptive functioning established before age 18.
Delayed motor, language, and social milestones.

related_diagnoses.Autism Spectrum Disorder: Common comorbidity, can complicate assessment of intellectual functioning.
related_diagnoses.Depressive and Bipolar Disorders: Can occur throughout the range of severity of intellectual disability.

symptoms: Persistent difficulties in acquiring and using language
Deficits in comprehension or production of vocabulary
Difficulties following instructions of increasing length
Difficulties remembering new words and sentences
description: Deficits in language acquisition and use.
Substantially lower language abilities compared to peers.

related_diagnoses.Intellectual Disability (Intellectual De: Not attributed to, but may coexist

description: Persistent difficulty with speech sound production that interferes with speech intelligibility or prevents verbal communication of messages.
Difficulties are not attributable to congenital or acquired conditions.

related_diagnoses.Hearing or Other Sensory Impairment: May result in abnormalities of speech. Deficits of speech sound production may be associated with a hearing impairment...
related_diagnoses.Structural Deficits: Speech impairment may be due to structural deficits (e.g., cleft palate).

symptoms: Sound prolongations of consonants and vowels
Audible or silent blocking (filled or unfilled pauses in speech)
Circumlocutions (word substitutions to avoid problematic words)
Words produced with an excess of physical tension
description: Disturbance in the normal fluency and time patterning of speech.
Interference with academic or occupational achievement or social communication.
Persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction.
Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities.

related_diagnoses.Social (Pragmatic) Communication Disorde: May be diagnosed instead if symptoms don't fully meet criteria for ASD
related_diagnoses.Intellectual Disability (Intellectual De: Frequently co-occurs; social communication should be below that expected for general developmental level to diagnose both conditions.

symptoms: Severe deficits in verbal and nonverbal social communication skills
Very limited initiation of social interactions
Minimal response to social overtures from others
Other restricted/repetitive behaviors causing significant interference with functioning
description: Persistent impairment in reciprocal social communication and social interaction
Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities

symptoms: Absent, reduced, or atypical social interest
Inappropriate approaches seeming aggressive or disruptive
Lack of shared social play and imagination
Insistence on playing by very fixed rules
Difficulty understanding appropriate behavior in different situations
Misunderstanding how language is used (e.g., irony)
Preference for solitary activities or interacting with people significantly younger or older
Desire to establish friendships without a complete idea of what they entail
Excessive adherence to routines and rigid patterns of behavior
Highly restricted, fixated interests with abnormal intensity or focus
Extreme reactions to sensory input (e.g., sounds, textures)
description: Social communication deficits judged against norms for age, gender, and culture.
Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities.

related_diagnoses.Intellectual Disability: May coexist with autism spectrum disorder.
related_diagnoses.Language Impairment: Commonly associated with autism spectrum disorder.

symptoms: Difficulties in early childhood and early school years
Developmental gains in later childhood in some areas
Behavioral deterioration during adolescence for a small proportion
Difficulties organizing practical demands without aid
Compensation strategies used to mask difficulties in public
Impairments causing current functioning issues in social, occupational, or other important areas
description: A neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by persistent deficits in social communication and interaction across multiple contexts.
Defined by the presence of restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities.

related_diagnoses.Rett syndrome: May exhibit similar symptoms during regression phase but improves later.
related_diagnoses.Selective mutism: Early development not typically disturbed, appropriate communication in certain contexts.
related_diagnoses.Language disorders and social (pragmatic: Problems of communication and secondary social difficulties without abnormal nonverbal communication or restricted/repetitive patterns of behavior.
related_diagnoses.Intellectual disability (intellectual de: Differentiation can be challenging in young children. Appropriate if no significant discrepancy between social-communicative skills and other intellectual skills.

symptoms: Overly focused or easily distracted attention
description: Persistent pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity interfering with functioning or development.
Difficulty sustaining attention, finishing tasks, staying organized.

related_diagnoses.autism spectrum disorder: may coexist, requiring dual diagnosis if criteria for both are met
related_diagnoses.other comorbid mental disorders: common, including anxiety disorders, depressive disorders, etc.

description: A persistent pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity interfering with functioning or development.
Manifests as wandering off task, lacking persistence, disorganization, and impulsive behaviors.

related_diagnoses.antisocial personality disorder: increased likelihood for substance use disorders and incarceration
related_diagnoses.substance use disorders: elevated risk, especially when conduct disorder or antisocial personality disorder develops

description: a disorder characterized by persistent patterns of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that impairs functioning or development

related_diagnoses.oppositional defiant disorder: may resist work or school tasks that require self-application due to negativity, hostility, and defiance
related_diagnoses.intermittent explosive disorder: high levels of impulsive behavior, but does not include serious aggression towards others nor inattention issues like ADHD
related_diagnoses.autism spectrum disorder: similar social dysfunction and peer rejection, but distinct in terms of social disengagement, isolation, and communication cues
related_diagnoses.reactive attachment disorder: shows social disinhibition but lacks the full ADHD symptom cluster and displays different features
related_diagnoses.anxiety disorders: shared symptoms of inattention, but differs in cause - ADHD due to attraction to external stimuli while anxiety due to worry and rumination
related_diagnoses.depressive disorders: presents with inability to concentrate, but only during a depressive episode
related_diagnoses.bipolar disorder: includes increased activity, poor concentration, and impulsivity episodically accompanied by elevated mood, grandiosity, etc.
related_diagnoses.disruptive mood dysregulation disorder: characterized by pervasive irritability and intolerance of frustration, but impulsiveness and disorganized attention are not essential features
related_diagnoses.substance use disorders: differentiation may be problematic if the first presentation of ADHD symptoms follows the onset of abuse or frequent use.

description: A neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by persistent patterns of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity.

related_diagnoses.Anxiety Disorders: More common than in the general population.
related_diagnoses.Major Depressive Disorder: Occurs less frequently than anxiety disorders but still higher than average.
related_diagnoses.Intermittent Explosive Disorder: Present in some adults with ADHD.
related_diagnoses.Substance Use Disorders: Relatively more frequent among adults with ADHD in the general population but affects a minority.
